comments.commentBody:
Thank you, Paul Krugman, for addressing the elephant in the living room. Even as extreme heat and drought devastate the midwest, the St. Louis Post-Dispatch will not mention the words global warming.

Thank you also, Expat, for bringing up the point that while global warming is melting icecaps and glaciers internationally, the effects people are most likely to be experiencing first-hand is "weather instability." No one can deny that we've been seeing an increase in wildly erratic weather extremes.

You are also right to point out that these extreme fluctuations are the most dangerous, for they are impossible to adapt to. Not only is this is an agricultural nightmare, the effects on the natural world could be even more devastating.

Ecosystems adapt to naturally-occurring climate change over expanses of thousands of years, but cannot adapt to extremes without consistent patterns. What happens to the oak-hickory forest that covers much of our nation, and those life forms dependent on it, when one year might bring fierce wind storms, monsoon-like rains and floods, and the next year extreme heat and drought? Weakened by extremes, the forests we take for granted could be devastated. Even the local park, and the beloved old tree in one's front yard.

Bring the argument home to people. Melting ice caps and glaciers may be the most consistent scientific indicators, but it is the wildly fluctuating local weather and its risks that people would be most likely to relate to.

While the variability of weather may appear to follow statistical patterns, there are causes of individual events and changing patterns. There are reasons why the weather is becoming more "unpredictable" in the sense that it is not following historical patterns.

What is the one most distinctive climate change in the past 10 years? The melting ice cap over the Arctic Ocean, which has thinned more each summer.

The focus of journalists has been on the rising ocean levels from melting ice, the polar bears, and a possible shift in the Gulf Stream. They may have missed the most important impact: changes in the jet stream We see the enormous effect of the jet stream each winter, when a shift in latitude can move snow and biting cold to the Carolinas, the Midwest, or the Northeast.

But what if the jet stream loses steam, slows down, meanders erratically year-round? Then you will have changes in seasonal patterns, early warming followed by bud-killing frost, downpours alternating with drought, and in some places, yes, unseasonably cold winters and summers. According to Jennifer Francis of Rutgers, the jet stream is already slowing.

So, not only does global warming promise more severe weather, the jet stream changes could bring more erratic weather. Erratic, unpredictable weather could be the most dangerous, because it would be almost impossible to adapt to, in terms of agriculture. This could lead to crop failures, both on massive and local scales, higher prices and famine.
What could be more efficient than killing off the landowners?

The dice example is a useful way to illustrate change, without going into details as to why the probability distribution in the die has been affected by various factors that are both human induced as well as natural cycles beyond human controls.

The use of the dice-rolling example to explain how week-to-week or year-to-year weather variability does not refute an inevitable global warming is an effective way to make the point. It should be persuasive to any reasonable person.

The problem, however, as Paul Krugman knows, is that the deniers of climate change tend either to be unreasonable people who are wilfully ignorant or people whose short-run economic interest is to forestall the energy decisions which would accompany general recognition that climate change is real.

The most effective argument made by climate change deniers is the notion that we cannot know where the world stands on the timeline of varying temperatures. Are we in the midst of a 200-year warming anomaly preceded by (and likely to be followed by) thousands of years of stable or even cooling climate?

We need better dissemination of the available information, such as core samples taken from around the world which do show where we stand on the timeline. We need that historical record to be presented with simple examples and models, as easy to understand as the Krugman (or Hansen) dice-rolling analogy.

There are others, including the Scandinavian countries who are preparing more diligently to provide as much as they possibly can to a majority of the citizenry. In the US, with our predominate Social Darwinist mentality, the minority will be provided for while the rest of us are left to fend for ourselves. Like climate change, this will seem at first to just be a natural fluctuation of economic and societal change, but eventually it will be cataclysmic for the majority our people. Yes, the unfortunate and cliched frog in a gradually boiling pot analogy holds.

Now, everyone can see the glaciers are melting away and it is theorized that the interiors of the continents will become desert as the increasing temperatures will change the paths of storms over the continents.  The world needs 70% more energy by 2020 and there will be 9 billion people on spaceship Earth by 2030.  The only solution is solar/wind power and electric cars.  I am sick and tired of seeing the coal industry run their ads about using coal.  They should be spending their money to find ways to tap the energy in coal with the least amount of carbon dioxide emissions!  Remember, we only have one spaceship Earth and one just needs to gaze at Venus to understand the horrors of a runaway greenhouse effect.  Ironically, by saving Mother Earth, we save the human species!

US citizens have allowed their elected representatives to slide by the unambiguously restrictive language of the Constitution since WWII and the UTTERLY IRRELEVANT examples of combat justification cited by Underwood.

The means of inflicting such death are also mostly irrelevant. The testosterone-fueled idiocracy that has dragged this country into undeclared wars time and again since Korea, with the full complicity of a majority of voters each time, is determined to do it yet again in central Asia, and we stupidly wonder why our nation is so dissolute after nonsense like Vietnam, Iraq, etc. Absent that declaration of war, we (& our elected reps) are MURDERERS!

We voters have the power to vote ANYONE thus inclined out of office, INCLUDING Barack Obama, and it is high time we took responsibility for what is going on. No, Mitt Romney is probably no better; he may be much worse, but Obama has broken faith with those of us who put him in the White House 4 years ago. He has to go.

H. Watkins Ellerson
PO Box 90
Hadensville, VA 23067

The problem here is that there are no front lines and this unannounced manhunt has no clear targets. So no, you cannot put a "certain philosopher" there. That is what what makes this moral dilemma so acute.

I WWII soldiers fired artillery into buildings where sniper fire came from. there was not question of other inhabitants. when invading a town, the GIs would go down a street and throw a grenade into the doors of each building they came to. And there was the carpet bombing of cities and the incendiary bombing of Tokyo among others.

You could consider a drone as simply a long range sniper. The operator has a target and zeroes in on him, no different than targeting him at 600 yards. The problem with this article is it uses the term "Suspected Militant." Either the target is a militant or he is not, which is it? From what we can read, these targets are identified and watched before being taken out.

It would be tempting to simply eliminate a whole village if it harbored these people, and that is what the Nazis would have done. We do not conduct warfare that way, we conduct civilized warfare. No matter, these targets are legitimate ones, and they have made themselves so by their actions. the moral dilemma exists more in the minds of certain philosophers than in reality.

Put them on the front lines for a period of time and I suspect their moral view will not be so indecisive.

How should we think about the relationship between climate change and day-to-day experience?

Well, a responsible, reasonable person might answer that we have a serious problem that isn't going to go away by wishing it away, or be denied simply because those with interests develop programs of denial; and we must do something serious about it, and pretty soon, or everyone's everyday life probably will be negatively affected.

Yet, that same reasonable person may have a wife and a couple of kids; and may be middle-aged with the kids getting set for college that even with student loans is going to cost pretty serious money (imagine that they're thinking of Princeton, Professor). He holds down a well-paid mid-management job in a medium-sized company whose health already is volatile because it's tied to consumer demand for non-essential goods; their cash reserves aren't real high; and they have some voracious competition, some of it foreign.

Now, the ripple effect of higher energy costs to reduce carbon emissions touches absolutely everything. Too much cost, and companies get downsized; and, these days, it's typically the middle-aged mid-manager that gets downsized. But, then, so does his wife and his kids and his dreams -- that middle-aged mid-level manager isn't likely to find a similar job too easily somewhere else in a bad economy.

Now, multiply that concern by millions. We may not be able to get to climate change until we have a more stable economy and jobs picture.
Al Gore stepped up, remember?  Americans instead bought in to the compassionate conservative.

Professor Krugman wants politicians -- voted in by an electorate, half of whom have IQs of 100 and less -- to (1) Accept that Climate Change is happening; and (2) Vote to spend money and enact Laws and Regulations to force Americans to do something about it? Rots of Ruck!

We can't even get politicians to enact laws to constrain the free distribution of assault weapons of destruction -- when it clearly makes no sense to allow people to freely buy machine guns that hold 100 rounds of ammunition.

What we need is Leadership from the President and Statesmen in Congress. Sometimes in history such Leaders step forth... but the truth is, they are few and far in between.

Right now, sadly, when we need these people, none have stepped up.

Kenneth,

Such variations have occured in the recent past and are well documented. Some have been warmer variations lasting a few to many years and some have been colder also lasting a few to many years. It was warm enough that settlers moved to Greenland around 1000 A.D. The climate then reversed condeming the settlers to a slow death by snow and cold. Europe suffered through a "Mini Ice Age in the middle ages and America had unusually cold years in the 1700s.

I am old enough to remember that the same sort of Weather Experts who are telling us today to fear Global Warming were telling us 50 years ago the interglacial period was ending and we were headed back into an ice age and we should burn more coal.

Unlike most here I actualy have purchased and installed Solar and other "Green" technology without any Government rebates or assistance. Keeping our homes as clean as possible and saving energy makes sense to me.

Turning our lives over to "Experts" and Politicians who lecture us and than live like Tsars in palaces seems to me to be a dubious idea. Likewise until China is willing to stop burning Coal and the third world is willing to stop slash and burn agriculture we are going to have a dificult time reducing the increases in CO2 to even see if it is in fact the source of the problem.

In the case of the environment that means taking a conservative approach to the risk of global warming. Even if the climate change science is wrong the risk is so great that we need to be cautious and prudent.

It is our duty to our children to be true conservatives. It is simply prudent to say that each and every one of us will today sacrifice just a little of our wealth in order to safeguard our children from the risk of calamity tomorrow.

It isn't just the heat and the rising oceans. Increased absorption of CO2 by the oceans has sharply increased acidification. A recent issue of Science (13 July) reports on increased acidification of the waters off the Pacific coast of the US. The increased pH of the ocean has led to large die-offs of oyster larvae. I'm afraid that Dennis Meadows, one of the authors of Limits to Growth, had it right when he said that long-range planning was not a human survival trait for thousands of years; but it appears that our lack of foresight is going to doom our species.

This isn't a problem with the luxury of focusing on only one aspect as though we can flip a switch and stop a runaway motor.

The science has been corroborated and the wide-spread public is starting to sense an on-going problem surrounds them. Yes, the sources that aggravate global warming must be substantially reduced. That's going to take time, and even if all the sources were immediately turned off, like a spinning flywheel this global warming will continue but begin to decline from elevated levels.

What is imperative, and few discuss, is the immediate need to determine how agricultural patterns will change and preparations needed for alternate food production areas and alternate production methods. We'll probably also have to modify our diets.

Besides food scarcity, a major agricultural production shortage will force food prices to skyrocket. The effect on the economy will be the equivalent of skyrocketing gasoline prices. Demand for other products in the economy will plummet.

We need funding for a wide-spread, sustained, public information program about the threats created by the added atmospheric heat so the public can begin to see the connections, issues, and understand the choices.

Meanwhile, we're a nation of 300 million living in air-conditioned cubicles and depending on a fragile, vulnerable corporate farm system. This is a vulnerability we can unwind while an international effort is made to apply the brakes to the global-warming flywheel.

Liam Jumper

Plus, we can use the stimulus right now, borrowing at very low interest rates.

In Florida, rises in sea level tend to become obvious when hurricanes destroy mangrove forests (permanently) and shift beaches inland.  The two Atlantic coast hurricanes of 2004 destroyed a lot of expensive beachfront property in Indian River County, a sort of subtropical Hamptons for retirees and one of Mitt Romney's most productive fundraising areas.  The next hurricane will be brushed off as just another excuse for redecorating flooded houses and renourishing eroded beaches.  But at some point, it'll become apparent that the land is disappearing.  Miami Beach, Naples, and Fort Lauderdale will likely feel it earlier.

One easy start is to educate women worldwide and give them free access to birth control.  The fight for women's reproductive rights and education is of utmost importance in global population control.

You are mentioning the two fundamental unmentionables and correct on both counts. Coincidentally, both are abetted by the American right wing.

The unwillingness to fund family planning because of the abortion debate is heavily influencing the damage of one, and the wish for cheap immigrant labor and its dampening effect on wage rates is promoting the other.

It is not only "liberals" who are pro illegal immigrants -- at least they do it for well-meaning (if misguided) reasons.
The world is NOT running out of cheap oil. That's part of the problem!

Unfortunately, climate change is the symptom not the cause.

It is the symptom of population growth. World population has almost tripled from 2.5 billion in 1950 to over 7 billion now. That includes over a billion Chinese who now want cars, and over a billion Indians.

And climate change isn't the only symptom. During the last decade, gasoline prices in the US tripled according to CPI figures. That's because the world is running out of cheap oil. So far, food inflation has been tame within the US, because as Krugman mentions, the US is indeed a breadbasket for the world, but the recent spike in corn prices may be a frightening harbinger for the future.

Worldwide a billion people suffer from intermittent hunger.

Oil is finite, water resources are finite, land for growing food is finite. Birth rates must come down or death rates will go up.

The US needs new policies. One of those is an emphasis on smaller families. That most likely means some difficult choices. It is no longer acceptable to kick the can down the road.

First of all, we must recognize that countries like Mexico, which do not give free access to birth control and abortion, are guilty of human rights abuse, because they doom their poor to lives of deprivation and ultimately starvation.

Second we must make sure that women in the US have access to the full range of family planning services.

Third, we must end illegal immigration.

These policies are on neither party's radar.

how will ending illegal immigration change the growth of population?  Third world parents have lots of kids as a means off securing their old age. A few will live to support them in adulthood.  Making sure they all stay in their native countries won’t break that cycle.

So... can we stem the rush to frack, put the activity on the back burner while we the people (and the companies so anxious to make a profit at our risk) do more research into whether fracking CAN be made completely safe, with no repercussions?

Please?

The people with the money control the government and the resources and the ability to survive a cataclysmic global warming event. The oil and gas companies are sitting on an estimated $20 trillion dollars of excess product beyond the agreed upon caps to prevent the global environment from rising more than another degree. How can the common man fight against so much money and power? The only solution is to expose the propaganda. If people are waiting for some miracle to protect the planet from the abuses we're allowing, then we have already lost the planet.
